response:
Urgent neuroimaging is required to confirm a medullary lesion, distinguish ischaemic from haemorrhagic or mass lesions, and evaluate vertebrobasilar vessels; routine blood tests look for metabolic contributors and thrombolysis contraindications; extended blood work and CSF studies assess for demyelinating, inflammatory, infective or prothrombotic causes; cardiac investigations search for embolic sources.

investigations = ["Non-contrast CT brain", "CT angiogram of head and neck", "MRI of brain and brainstem with diffusion-weighted imaging and MR angiography of head and neck", "Full blood count", "Urea and electrolytes", "Liver function tests", "Coagulation screen", "Blood glucose", "HbA1c", "Lipid profile", "Erythrocyte sedimentation rate", "C-reactive protein", "Serum vitamin B12", "Serum folate", "Thyroid function tests", "Antinuclear antibody", "Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies", "Antiphospholipid antibody panel", "Electrocardiogram", "Transthoracic echocardiogram", "24-hour Holter monitor", "Lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid analysis including cell count, protein, glucose and oligoclonal bands (only if imaging does not show a clear infarct or suggests demyelination/inflammation)", "Nerve conduction studies and electromyography (if the reduced ankle reflex or distal sensory findings raise concern for coexistent peripheral neuropathy)"]
